name: Check passwords by hashes
description:
You are a junior developer in a company that uses some app with database and wants to improve the security of user passwords. So they want to check whether passwords are stronger than some random well-known word. Your task is to write a function that would check passwords for their presence in a given dictionary. For security reasons, you will only be provided with the SHA1 hashes (encoded in base64) of these passwords. As a developer you have enough privileges to get your job done, not just rights to select data as an usual user.

Database structure:

Table `dictionary`:
* `password` (text): well-known password

Function signature:
* name: `check_hashes`
* input parameters: 
  * `hashes` (text\[\]) - array of base64 encoded SHA1 hashes
* returning value: 
  * a table with 2 columns:
    * `hash` (text) - given hash from the input parameter
    * `password` (text) - password from the dictionary, if found. Otherwise - NULL
  
The result of the function should be ordered in the same way as the hashes in the input array.

Performance requirements:
* 100 tests with ~50 hashes each and ~100k passwords in the dictionary
* 100 tests with ~100 hashes each and ~100k passwords in the dictionary
* 100 tests with ~50 hashes each and ~200k passwords in the dictionary

Notes and hints: 
* The dictionary is changed only a very few times
* in a rare case of a collision any password (or even both in two lines) would be counted as a right answer
* you have enough DB rights to do everything you need to make your function fast enough
